column1: 32 in 1 (USA)>32 in 1 >1988>ESRB - E (Everyone)>Atari Corporation>Atari Corporation>Compilation>3.3>1-3 Players>This was a cart that was released in PAL format in Europe
column2: Australia and New Zealand. Most were the pack in game with the Atari 2600 in the UK and Atari 7800 in Australia and New Zealand but it was also released as a boxed separate game for the Atari 2600. A different game was selected every time the Atari 2600 or Atari 7800 was turned on.The games were: 1.UFO (a renaming of U. S. Game's Space Jockey) 2.Flag Capture 3.Human Cannonball 4.Reversi (a renaming of Atari's Othello) 5.Activision's Checkers 6.Slot Racers 7.Blackjack 8.Fishing (a graphic hack of Activision's Fishing Derby in which you are fishing for crabs) 9.Freeway Rabbit (a graphic hack of Activision's Freeway in which you are a rabbit) 10.Space War 11.Fun with Numbers 12.Golf 13.3-D Tic-Tac-Toe 14.Surround 15.Miniature Golf 16.Activision's Boxing 17.Football 18.Air-Sea Battle 19.Freeway Chicken (a renaming of Activision's Freeway) 20.Activision's Tennis 21.Activision's Skiing 22.Activision's Fishing Derby 23.Sky Diver 24.Bowling 25.Combat 26.Activision's Stampede 27.Activision's Laser Blast 28.Outlaw 29.Slot Machine 30.Basketball 31.Home Run 32.Ant Party (a renaming of CommaVid's Cosmic Swarm)

column1: Ace of Aces (USA)>Ace of Aces >1988>ESRB - E (Everyone)>Atari Corporation>Artech>Flying>2.0>1 Player>Ace of Aces is a 1st person
column2: 2D flight simulation. You're onboard a British RAF Mosquito
column3:
maverick fighter bomber.
Your mission ... stop enemy trains
column4: intercept the terrible german V-1 buzz bombs
column5: sink the german U-boats and down the Nazi bombers. Are you ready for this challenge?

column1: Alien Brigade (USA)>Alien Brigade >1990>ESRB - E (Everyone)>Atari Corporation>Atari Corporation>Shooter>4.0>1 Player>Alien Brigade is a side scrolling shooter similar to Operation Wolf. Aliens have arrived on earth and have brainwashed both soldiers and civilians in order to take over the world. Your job is to stop them! On each of the five levels you will have a different objective to complete
column2: including saving civilians and destroying alien installations. Throughout the levels there will be numerous aliens and brainwashed people you will need to shoot
column3: as well as attacking tanks
column4: helicopters
column5: and more. After shooting enemies a bonus may sometimes be left behind; if you shoot this
column6: you can earn additional ammo
column7: more powerful weapons
column8: or increased health. If you don't shoot fast enough and are hit by enemy fire your health will slowly decrease; the game ends when all of your health is gone.

column1: Asteroids (USA)>Asteroids >1987>ESRB - E (Everyone)>Atari Corporation>tari
column2:
Inc.>Shoot-'Em-Up>3.8>1-2 Players>Asteroids is a conversion of the arcade game of the same name.
Play the role of a spaceship pilot trapped in a gigantic asteroid cloud and pulverize incoming asteroids with the ship's photon cannon. When all asteroids are destroyed
column3: the play can them move to the next round. In addition to asteroid
column4:
the player will also face an Alien Robot Saucer which shoots randomly across the screen.
The player using the controller may rotate the ship (left or right) to any direction or move the ship forward. Shots will be fired according to the ship direction. The player has three reserved ships available to replace a destroyed spaceship. The spaceship is destroyed if an asteroid collides with the spaceship or is shot by an Alien Robot Saucer. Additionally
column5: the player may opt to use the hyperspace warp to avoid collision. The warp however
column6:
may also destroy the spaceship in the process.
Asteroids when shot will break-up into smaller pieces or be destroyed.. There are three types of asteroids: large asteroids
column7: medium asteroids
column8: and small asteroids. Large asteroids and medium asteroids when shot
column9:
will break-up into two smaller sized asteroids. Small asteroids when shot will be destroyed.
Alien Robot Saucers come in two sizes: small and large. Both use photon lasers to shoot and will explode when destroyed. Alien Robot Saucers will not appear at the Novice Level.
Game Difficulty and Variations
There are 4 available difficulty settings: Novice
column10: Intermediate
column12:
and Expert.
The game also offers three different game variations:
1. Standard Play - For one or two players
column13:
taking turns when a player's ship is destroyed.
2. Competition Asteroids - Two players appear on the screen at the same time. Friendly fire is in affect
column14:
which means shots fired from one player's spaceship will destroy the other player's spaceship. Each player has separate ship reserves.
3. Team Asteroids - Two players on the screen at the same time. Friendly fire is disabled
column15:
which means shots fired from one player's spaceship will not destroy the other player's spaceship and just pass through. Ship reserves for both players are combined.
Scoring
The score of the Player 1 is viewable on the upper left side of the screen
column16: while Player 2 on the opposite upper right side. A player will be awarded a new reserve ship for every 10
column18:
000 points
2. Other player's ship - 500 points
3. Large saucer - 200 points
4. Small asteroid - 100 points
5. Medium asteroid - 50 points
6. Large asteroid - 20 points

column1: Ballblazer (USA)>Ballblazer >1987>ESRB - E (Everyone)>Atari Corporation>Lucasfilm Games LLC>Sports>3.8>1-2 Players>In the year 3037
column2: the most competitive sport in the known universe is Ballblazer. For the first time ever
column3: humans from the planet Earth have won the right to compete in the final round of the Ballblazer Championship
column4:
to fight for Earth's honor and the title Masterblazer!
Ballblazer is a 3D futuristic soccer-like game
column5: where the player (inside a Rotofoil) is set on a one-on-one 1
column6:
155 square playing field (the Grid). The objective of the player to kick a floating ball (Plasmorb) inside the opponent's goal (Goalbeams). A player may compete against a human or computer opponent.
The Rotofoil is equipped with a multi-purpose forcefield. This forcefield when in short distance of the Plasmorb will act as a pull field
column7: automatically pulling the Plasmorb towards to player. When a player in possession of the Plasmorb shoots
column8: the forcefield will act as push field and launches the ball. When the match starts
column9:
the player must move down field and attempt to gain possession of the Plasmorb using the joystick and blast the Plasmorb to an intended direction.
The player should also be aware that the Goldbeams move slightly every second and the distance between them will shrink. The highest scoring goals are goals made when Goldbeams have disappeared across the horizon (Over The Horizon/OTH shots). A player may also attempt to steal possession of a Plasmorb by rushing beside the opponent and blast the Plasmorb away. The game ends when time runs out or a player wins 10 consecutive goals. If the game ends in a draw
column10:
over-time will apply and the first player to score will win the game.
Scoring
Close-in goals - 1 point
Goals near Goldbeams - 2 points
OTH shots - 3 points
Players may steal points from each other by making goals.
The total combined score of both players cannot accede more than 10 points.
A player winning 10 consecutive points automatically

column1: Barnyard Blaster (USA)>Barnyard Blaster >1988>ESRB - E (Everyone)>Atari Corporation>Atari Corporation>Gun>2.2>1-2 Players>You and your grandpa just put your life savings into buying a small farm a few acres for growing vegetables and raising horses
column2:
a place to get away from the battle of city life. But you discover that the entire farm is full of things that are determined to drive you away.
Barnyard Blaster is a shooting gallery type game for use with the Atari XG-1 light gun or the joystick. There are three levels plus one bonus level.Your goal is to rid your farm of vermin by shooting targets in each of three levels. Between each level you'll play Gramps' bonus screen where you can brush up on your shooting. But in order to proceed through each level
column3: you must achieve a certain percentage of shooting accuracy. At the end of the game you're given a ranking depending on how well you did.

column1: Basketbrawl (USA)>Basketbrawl >1990>ESRB - E (Everyone)>Atari Corporation>Atari Corporation>Basketball/Sports>2.2>1-2 Players>In a desperate attempt to stop inner-city gang wars
column2: the city leaders organized a basketball league. The league is scheduled to play on three courts: a street
column3: a junkyard
column4:
and a rooftop. The mayor figured that a friendly game of hoops would be a much more peaceful way to settle disputes. He was wrong.
You can choose 1-on-1 or 2-on-2 game modes. There are six characters to choose from (ten in Atari Lynx version); each with their own health
column5: speed
column6: and power attributes. Each player without the ball can jump to block a shot or punch there opponent to get the ball. There's also an option to perform a power throw on an opposing player. Players with the ball can shoot or pass. Power ups appear on the court at random instances. These power up one attribute for the player. For example
column7:
the lightning power up increases the player's speed.
The referee does not call fouls
column8: but does hurl knives at the players.

column1: Centipede (USA)>Centipede >1987>ESRB - E (Everyone)>Atari Corporation>Atari Corporation>Shoot-'Em-Up>4.2>1-2 Players>In Centipede
column2: the player is trapped in the Enchanted Forest. Armed with only a magic wand to ward off the forest's insect denizens
column3:
all of which apparently are attacking in the player in continuous waves.
The player must use the magic wand to shoot sparks at approaching insects to score points by pressing the controller button. Holding down the controller button will set the wand to rapid fire shots. If the player is bitten by an insect
column4:
the player will be temporarily paralyzed and lose one of the three starting magic wands.
Insect Opponents and Mushrooms
All enemy insects have a distinctive sound before attacking
column5:
which may help the player identify which insect is attacking. Enemies and objects in the game are as the following:
1. The Centipede
The Centipede will attack in 12 waves. In the first wave
column6: the Centipede will have a head attached to 11 body segments. In the second wave
column7: the Centipede will have a head attached to 10 body segments
column8: in addition to a detached head. The third wave will have the Centipede with an attached head
column9: 9 body segments
column10: plus two detached heads. These body segments will transform into heads and continue to do so until Wave 12. In the last wave
column11: the Centipede will have 12 detached heads
column12:
independently attacking the player. Centipede heads are worth more points than body segments.
Attacks from the Centipede will come from the top of the screen
column13: moving downward. If a spark hits any part of the Centipede
column14: that particular body segment will transform into a mushroom
column15: while the body segment behind it will become the new Centipede head. When the Centipede is destroyed
column16:
it will briefly disappear and re-appear from the top of the screen again.
The Spider
The Spider will attempt to distract the player from attacking the Centipede. It will destroy any mushroom it touches. Spiders will score more points if it is hit in closer distances.
The Flea
The Flea will appear if the player has destroyed most of the existing mushrooms. It will drop down creating a new batch of mushrooms where it falls. The Flea will disappear after two hits. After the first hit
column17:
the Flea will drop down much faster.
The Scorpion
The Scorpion will appear in the third wave. It moves slowly but will pick up speed
column19:
it will poison any mushroom it touches.
Mushrooms
Mushrooms fill the Enchanted Forest and may act as obstacles or cover for the player
column20:
with added effects to enemy insects. It takes for shots to complete destroy a mushroom. There are two type of mushrooms: Magic Mushrooms and Poisonous mushrooms. Magic mushrooms are the default mushrooms in the game and are also the the result of the player destroying an insect or Centipede body segment. Poisonous Mushrooms are the result of the Scorpion touching a mushroom. Poisonous Mushrooms will prompt the Centipede near it to move straight towards the player through any mushroom. Losing a wand will restore any partially damaged mushroom.
Game Difficulty and Variations
The game offers four difficulty levels: Novice
column23:
and Expert. Game Variations are as the following:
1. One Player
Two Player Alternating
Two players will take turns when the active player is bitten.
Dual Player Competition
Two players will appear on the screen at the same time. Scoring is separate. Shots fired from one player will paralyze the other player.
Team Play
Two players will appear on the screen at the same time. Scoring is combined. Shots fired from one player will not paralyze the other player.
Scoring
The player will win a bonus magic wand for every 12
column24:
000 points to a maximum of six wands. The game will end when all wands are lost. Scoring are as the following:
Centipede Head - 100 points
Centipede Body Segment - 10 points
Spider at close range - 900 points
Spider at medium range - 600 points
Flea - 200 points
Scorpion - 1
column25:
000 points
Flea - 200 points
Restored mushroom - 5 points
Destroyed mushroom - 1 points

column1: Choplifter! (USA)>Choplifter! >1988>ESRB - E (Everyone)>Atari Corporation>Brøderbund Software
column2: Inc.>Shoot-'Em-Up>2.4>1 Player>Choplifter is a side-scrolling action/arcade game that puts you in command of an attack chopper. Your mission: Go behind enemy lines and rescue up to 16 hostages per level. Be careful
column3: though
column4:
because tanks and enemy aircraft will try to stop you -- and they won't stop shooting while you are rescuing those hostages!
Originally released for Apple II home computers
column5: Choplifter was later ported to the arcades and a number of video game consoles. Many imitators and homages would follow.

column1: Commando (USA)>Commando >1989>ESRB - E (Everyone)>Atari Corporation>Capcom Co.
column2: Ltd.>Shooter>4.2>1-2 Players>Several levels await your super-tough Commando in this arcade conversion. Armed with only a standard rifle and a few grenades you must take on hordes of Nazis. Some are wandering around in the open
column3: while others have picked out hiding places
column4: which you must approach from certain angles. Trees
column5: rivers and bridges create a varied combat-like terrain and must be incorporated into your thinking. Extra grenades can be collected
column6: and will definitely be required
column7: as they allow you to kill form distance and thus avoid some enemy shots.

column1: Crack'ed (USA)>Crack'ed >1988>ESRB - E (Everyone)>Atari Corporation>Atari Corporation>Shooter>3.0>1 Player>As a professional ornithologist
column2: you're thrilled to find out that some rare South American hornbills have nested in your "old yolk tree. But while the hornbills are out feeding
column3: a group of mischievous bluebirds
column4: owls
column5:
and snakes begin raiding their nests and stealing eggs.
You get out your slingshot and begin hitting the marauding creatures. But you have to be careful. If you hit an egg-carrying bird

column1: Crossbow (USA)>Crossbow >1987>ESRB - E (Everyone)>Atari Corporation>Exidy
column2: Inc.>Shooter>2.9>1 Player>In Crossbow
column3: you and several friends are trying to cross many treacherous landscapes in order to retrieve stolen treasures from the castle of the Evil Master. All of the members of your party are unarmed
column4: however you carry a crossbow. Using this
column5: you need to shoot any obstacles or hostile enemies that may get in the way of your friends as they cross the screen. You see the landscape from a first person point of view
column6: and one by one each member of the party will walk from the left to right on the screen. There are many different landscapes that need to be crossed
column7: each with its own variety of dangers. There are deserts with scorpions
column8: ice caverns
column9: jungles with hostile monkeys
column10: a lava spewing volcano
column11: and even the heavily guarded castle. The game starts with two friends in your party

column1: Dark Chambers (USA)>Dark Chambers >1988>ESRB - E (Everyone)>Atari Corporation>Atari Corporation>Maze>2.0>1-2 Players>Dark Chambers is an arcade action game similar to Gauntlet. You are an explorer in an underground maze; your goal is to survive the 26 different levels and collect as many of the hidden treasures as you can. Hidden somewhere in each of the levels is an exit which will take you on to the next level. Trying to stop you from completing your quest are a wide variety of creatures
column2: including zombies
column3: wraiths
column4: skeletons
column5: wizards
column6: and the grim reaper. Each of the creatures in the game has a different strength; when you shoot a creature
column7: it will transform into the next weaker creature. Eventually a creature will become the weakest one (a zombie) at which point it can be destroyed. In addition to the creatures and treasures
column8: other items that can be found in the maze are keys (to open doors)
column9: potions (to restore health)
column10: poison (drains health)
column14: and bombs. The game is played from an overhead point of view
column15: and is for one player or two players simultaneously.

column1: Desert Falcon (USA)>Desert Falcon >1987>ESRB - E (Everyone)>Atari Corporation>Atari Corporation>Shoot-'Em-Up>3.2>1 Player>Desert Falcon is an arcade style shooter. Many of the Pharaoh's great treasures are lost throughout the desert
column2: and your goal is to steal as many as you can to earn points. The game features a scrolling
column3: isometric point of view as you control your falcon through the various desert landscapes. The treasures you are after are guarded of course. Many desert creatures including vultures

column5: flying fish
column6: sphinxes and more will all attempt to stop you from succeeding in your task. Also

column14: trick enemies into attacking a decoy instead of you
column15: or even get an air bomb which destroys all airborne enemies.

column1: Dig Dug (USA)>Dig Dug >1987>ESRB - E (Everyone)>Atari Corporation>Namco Limited>Maze>3.8>1-2 Players>Dig Dug is a 1-2 player arcade game in which you have to use your shovel to dig your way through the earth. Stopping you from doing this are two monsters

column4: which you can use to inflate the monsters to the point where they explode. (if you start to inflate them but stop doing so

column7: and you can use these rocks to squash them. If the monsters do not find you for several seconds
column8: they will eventually get turned into ghosts
column9: which are able to walk through the earth. They are invincible and cannot be killed. From time to time
column10: vegetables will appear in the center
column11: and you can get these for points.

column1: Donkey Kong (USA)>Donkey Kong >1988>ESRB - E (Everyone)>Atari Corporation>Nintendo Co.
column2: Ltd.>Platform>3.6>1-2 Players>Released in the arcades in 1981
column3: Donkey Kong was not only Nintendo's first real smash hit for the company
column4:
but marked the introduction for two of their most popular mascots: Mario (originally "Jumpman") and Donkey Kong.
Donkey Kong is a platform-action game that has Mario scale four different industrial themed levels (construction zone
column5: cement factory
column6: an elevator-themed level
column7: and removing rivets from girders) in an attempt to save the damsel in distress
column8: Pauline
column9: from the big ape before the timer runs out. Once the rivets are removed from the final level
column10: Donkey Kong falls
column11: and the two lovers are reunited. From there
column12:
the levels start over at a higher difficulty.
Along the way
column13: Mario must dodge a constant stream of barrels
column15: and spring-weights. Although not as powerful as in other future games
column16: Mario can find a hammer which allows him to destroy the barrels and fireballs for a limited amount of time. Additionally
column17: Mario can also find Pauline's hat
column18:
purse and umbrella for additional bonus points.
Donkey Kong is also notable for being one of the first complete narratives in video game form
column19: told through simplistic cut scenes that advance the story. It should also be noted that in versions of the game for early 1980's consoles
column20: Donkey Kong only used 2-3 of the original levels
column21: with the cement factory usually omitted.

column1: Donkey Kong Junior (USA)>Donkey Kong Junior >1988>ESRB - E (Everyone)>Atari Corporation>Nintendo Co.
column2:
Ltd.>Platform>2.9>1-2 Players>Mario has kidnapped Junior's Papa!

column4: finally having captured Donkey Kong
column5: and has put the ape in a locked cage. As Donkey Kong Jr.
column6: players will have to make their way through four different levels (Vines
column7: Springboard
column8:
Chains and Mario's Hideout) in an attempt to find keys to free the little monkey's Father.
Along the way
column9: Mario will send out Snapjaws
column10: swooping purple birds
column11: and electric sparks in an attempt to stop Junior. Junior can defend himself by dropping fruit found around the levels on the heads of his foes. The more foes a piece of fruit hits in a falling sequence

the higher bonus points can be scored.
Junior can also avoid enemies more easily by grabbing hold of two chains or vines at a time to climb away faster

column14:
any long fall or falling into the water on certain levels will mean the loss of a life for Junior.
In the final cut scene

column16:
the game levels will start over at a higher difficulty.
Like the original Donkey Kong
column17: the earlier 1980's console versions do not have all of the levels and animations from the arcade.

Using whatever techniques they have at their disposal
